definitions: telephone communication or attempt to speak with someone remotely
scheduled visit by a professional service provider to a location
loud cry or shout intended to attract attention or summon someone
judgment or decision made by an official in sports or other contexts
financial contract giving the holder the right to buy an asset at a specific price
examples: She received an urgent call from her mother last night
The conference call included participants from twelve different countries
The plumber scheduled a service call for Tuesday afternoon
Emergency calls doubled during the holiday weekend rush
The hunter's call echoed through the misty mountain valley
She heard her daughter's call from the playground nearby
The umpire's controversial call changed the game's momentum entirely
That was a tough call but someone had to decide
He purchased call options on technology stocks before earnings
The call expires worthless if prices don't reach strike

definitions: large musical instrument with steam whistles played by keyboard, commonly used in circuses
muse of epic poetry and eloquence in Greek mythology
examples: The circus calliope's cheerful music announced the parade's arrival downtown
Steam powered the vintage calliope aboard the Mississippi riverboat
Artists often invoked Calliope for inspiration in epic literary works
The statue depicted Calliope holding her traditional writing tablet

definitions: unit of energy equal to the amount needed to raise one gram of water by one degree Celsius
measure of potential energy that food provides when consumed by the body
examples: Scientists measured the reaction's energy output in calories per gram
One kilocalorie equals one thousand calories in scientific measurement
The nutrition label showed each serving contained two hundred calories
She tracked her daily calorie intake using a mobile application

definitions: hill outside Jerusalem where Jesus Christ was crucified according to Christian tradition
experience of intense mental or physical suffering resembling Christ's passion
sculptural or artistic representation of the crucifixion scene often displayed outdoors
examples: Pilgrims visit Calvary to commemorate Christ's sacrifice for humanity
The Church of the Holy Sepulchre encompasses the traditional Calvary site
Her long illness became a personal calvary for the entire family
The soldier's calvary lasted through three years of captivity
The stone calvary stood at the village crossroads for centuries
Medieval artisans carved elaborate calvaries throughout the French countryside

definitions: theological system emphasizing predestination and salvation by faith alone developed by John Calvin
examples: Calvinism spread rapidly through Switzerland and France during the Reformation
The five points of Calvinism summarize its core theological principles

definitions: person who follows or advocates the theological teachings of John Calvin
examples: The Calvinist congregation established churches throughout colonial New England
Strict Calvinists believe divine election determines salvation before birth

definitions: Caribbean musical style with improvised lyrics on topical themes originating in Trinidad
sea nymph in Greek mythology who detained Odysseus on her island
examples: The calypso singer improvised witty verses about current political events
Steel drums accompanied the lively calypso performance at carnival
Calypso kept Odysseus on her island Ogygia for seven years
The nymph Calypso offered Odysseus immortality if he stayed

definitions: rotating mechanical part that converts rotary motion into linear motion in engines
digital camera device used for video communication or surveillance
examples: The engine's cam shaft controlled the valve timing precisely
Worn cams caused irregular engine performance requiring immediate replacement
She positioned the cam for better lighting during video calls
Security cams monitored the building entrance twenty-four hours daily

definitions: first geological period of the Paleozoic era marked by rapid evolution of complex life forms
examples: The Cambrian explosion produced most major animal phyla existing today
Trilobite fossils commonly date from the Cambrian period's marine deposits

definitions: legendary castle and court of King Arthur in Arthurian romance literature
period or place of idealized happiness, prosperity, and enlightened leadership
examples: Knights gathered at Camelot's round table to discuss noble quests
Medieval romances described Camelot as Britain's most magnificent castle
The Kennedy presidency became known as America's Camelot era retrospectively
Their startup's early days felt like Camelot before competition arrived

definitions: secret criminal organization originating in Naples, Italy, involved in organized crime activities
examples: The Camorra controlled illegal gambling throughout the Naples region historically
Police conducted raids against suspected Camorra operations in southern Italy

definitions: disease caused by uncontrolled cell division that can spread throughout the body
fourth astrological sign of the zodiac symbolized by the crab
evil or destructive practice that spreads harmfully through society or groups
examples: Early cancer detection significantly improves treatment success rates worldwide
The oncologist specialized in treating rare forms of childhood cancer
People born under Cancer are considered nurturing and emotionally intuitive
The Cancer constellation appears brightest during March in northern skies
Corruption became a cancer destroying the organization from within gradually
The cancer of hatred spread through the community unchecked

definitions: political or administrative division of a country, particularly in Switzerland
upper corner section of a flag or heraldic shield
examples: Geneva canton maintains significant autonomy within the Swiss federal system
Each Swiss canton has its own constitution and governmental structure
The flag's canton displayed the national emblem against blue background
Heraldic rules specify exact proportions for the shield's canton placement

definitions: informal term for a Canadian person, sometimes considered mildly derogatory
examples: The Vancouver Canucks hockey team embraced the regional nickname proudly
American tourists often called their Canadian hosts Canucks affectionately

definitions: city serving as the seat of government for a country or region
wealth or assets available for investment or business operations
large form of a letter used at sentence beginnings or for proper nouns
decorated top portion of an architectural column or pillar
examples: Washington D.C. became the American capital in seventeen ninety-one permanently
The capital city housed all major government ministries and departments
Venture capital funded the biotech startup's research and development phase
The company raised capital through both equity and debt financing
Always write proper names with capital letters in formal documents
The title used decorative capital letters for dramatic visual effect
Corinthian capitals featured elaborate acanthus leaf designs carved in stone
The temple's capitals showed typical Ionic scroll patterns beautifully

definitions: building housing a legislative body, especially the U.S. Congress in Washington D.C.
examples: The United States Capitol dome dominates Washington's skyline impressively
State capitol buildings often feature neoclassical architectural designs throughout

definitions: tenth astrological sign of the zodiac associated with ambition and discipline
constellation in the southern sky representing a goat or sea-goat
mythological creature with a goat's head and fish's tail
examples: Capricorns are traditionally characterized as ambitious and practical individuals
The sun enters Capricorn around December twenty-second each year
The Capricorn constellation contains the star cluster Messier thirty
Ancient astronomers identified Capricorn among the zodiac constellations early
Medieval bestiaries depicted Capricorn as a fantastical sea-goat creature
The Capricorn symbol combines terrestrial and aquatic elements symbolically

definitions: genus of plants producing peppers ranging from sweet bell peppers to hot chili varieties
examples: Capsicum varieties include everything from mild bells to scorching habaneros
The greenhouse specialized in growing rare capsicum cultivars year-round

definitions: knitted sweater that opens at the front with buttons or zipper closure
examples: She wore a wool cardigan over her dress for extra warmth
The professor's tweed cardigan became his signature classroom attire

definitions: native or resident of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
lively Brazilian ballroom dance similar to the samba
examples: The carioca showed tourists the best beaches along Copacabana's coastline
True cariocas know all the hidden gems throughout Rio's neighborhoods
They performed the carioca with characteristic hip movements and energy
The carioca gained international popularity during nineteen thirties Hollywood films

definitions: member of a Roman Catholic religious order founded on Mount Carmel in the twelfth century
examples: The Carmelite monastery maintained strict contemplative practices for centuries
Saint Teresa reformed the Carmelite order in sixteenth century Spain

definitions: relating to the Frankish dynasty founded by Charlemagne ruling western Europe from 751-987 CE
examples: Carolingian manuscripts preserved classical texts through the Middle Ages
The Carolingian Renaissance revived learning and arts in medieval Europe

definitions: relating to the coordinate system using perpendicular axes developed by Descartes
relating to the philosophical methods and ideas of René Descartes
examples: Cartesian coordinates locate points using x and y axis values
The robot's movement followed Cartesian grid patterns precisely programmed
Cartesian dualism separates mind and body as distinct substances philosophically
His Cartesian approach emphasized systematic doubt and rational analysis

definitions: member of a strict contemplative Catholic monastic order founded by Saint Bruno in 1084
examples: Carthusian monks lived in individual cells maintaining near-total silence
The Carthusian monastery's architecture reflected their solitary lifestyle requirements

definitions: person who cuts or shapes materials, especially wood or stone, into artistic forms
knife or tool specifically designed for carving meat or other materials
examples: The master carver spent months creating the cathedral's wooden altarpiece
Ice carvers transformed frozen blocks into elaborate sculptures quickly
She used the electric carver to slice the turkey evenly
The carver's sharp blade made precise cuts through dense materials

definitions: money in coins or bills rather than checks or electronic payments
immediate payment at the time of purchase rather than credit
examples: She withdrew cash from the ATM for weekend shopping expenses
The store offered discounts for customers paying with cash
Cash transactions completed immediately without processing delays or fees
They demanded cash on delivery for all wholesale orders

definitions: fine, soft wool obtained from cashmere goats, used for high-quality garments
examples: The cashmere sweater felt incredibly soft against her skin
Genuine cashmere comes from goats raised in Mongolia and Kashmir

definitions: person who predicts disaster or misfortune, especially when warnings are disbelieved
Trojan princess in Greek mythology cursed to speak true prophecies that no one would believe
examples: Environmental scientists felt like Cassandras warning about climate change
The economist became a Cassandra, accurately predicting the market crash
Cassandra warned the Trojans about the wooden horse unsuccessfully
Apollo cursed Cassandra after she rejected his romantic advances

definitions: aromatic bark from certain trees used as a spice similar to cinnamon
genus of flowering plants in the legume family with yellow flowers
examples: Cassia adds warm, sweet flavor to Middle Eastern cuisine dishes
Chinese cassia bark differs slightly from Ceylon cinnamon in taste
The cassia trees bloomed with bright yellow flowers each spring
Tropical cassia species provide ornamental value in warm climate gardens

definitions: small wheel attached to furniture legs allowing easy movement
plant producing castor oil used in medicine and industry
one of the twin brothers in Greek mythology with Pollux
examples: The desk's castor wheels made rearranging the office simple
Heavy-duty castors supported the industrial equipment's considerable weight
Castor oil served as a traditional remedy for constipation
The castor plant's seeds contain highly toxic ricin compounds
Castor and Pollux became the constellation Gemini in mythology
Sailors prayed to Castor for protection during Mediterranean voyages

definitions: larval stage of butterflies and moths that feeds on plants before metamorphosis
brand name for heavy construction equipment with continuous track propulsion
examples: The caterpillar munched through tomato leaves in the garden voraciously
Monarch caterpillars feed exclusively on milkweed plants for protection
The construction crew used Caterpillar bulldozers to clear the site
Caterpillar equipment dominated the mining operation's heavy machinery fleet

definitions: member or relating to the Roman Catholic Church headed by the Pope
including a wide variety of things; all-embracing or universal in extent
examples: Catholic doctrine emphasizes papal authority and sacramental theology fundamentally
The Catholic population represents over one billion believers worldwide
Her catholic tastes in music ranged from classical to hip-hop
The museum's catholic collection represented every major art movement

definitions: religious faith, practice, and church order of the Roman Catholic Church
examples: Catholicism spread throughout Latin America during Spanish colonization historically
Modern Catholicism balances traditional doctrine with contemporary social issues

definitions: person of European ancestry with light skin color, though the term is scientifically outdated
person from the Caucasus region between the Black and Caspian seas
examples: Census forms previously used Caucasian to categorize white Americans
The term Caucasian originated from outdated racial classification theories
Caucasian languages include Georgian, Armenian, and numerous regional tongues
The Caucasian mountain communities maintained distinct cultural traditions historically

definitions: supporter of King Charles I during the English Civil War
showing a lack of proper concern; dismissive or offhand
examples: Cavaliers fought Parliamentary forces during England's seventeenth-century civil war
The cavalier wore elaborate clothing distinguishing him from Puritan roundheads
His cavalier attitude toward safety regulations endangered the entire team
She took a cavalier approach to deadlines, missing several important ones

definitions: member of ancient Indo-European peoples inhabiting Britain, Ireland, and Gaul before Roman times
prehistoric stone or metal implement with a beveled cutting edge
examples: Ancient Celts developed sophisticated metalworking techniques throughout Iron Age Europe
Celtic tribes resisted Roman expansion into Gaul and Britain
Archaeologists discovered bronze celts at the prehistoric settlement site
The stone celt showed signs of repeated sharpening and use

definitions: relating to the Celts or their languages, cultures, and traditions
branch of Indo-European languages including Irish, Scottish Gaelic, and Welsh
examples: Celtic art features intricate knotwork patterns and spiraling designs distinctively
The Celtic festival of Samhain influenced modern Halloween celebrations
Celtic languages survive primarily in Ireland, Scotland, and Wales today
Scholars study Celtic linguistics to understand prehistoric European migrations

definitions: current geological era beginning 66 million years ago, characterized by mammal and bird dominance
examples: The Cenozoic era followed the mass extinction ending the Mesozoic
Mammalian evolution accelerated dramatically during the Cenozoic era's progression

definitions: mythological creature with the upper body of a human and lower body of a horse
examples: The centaur Chiron taught heroes like Achilles in Greek mythology
Renaissance paintings often depicted centaurs symbolizing untamed nature's duality

definitions: point equally distant from all edges or extremities of something
building or place used for a particular activity or service
moderate political position between left and right extremes
examples: The sculpture stood at the centre of the circular plaza
Draw a line through the centre of the rectangle precisely
The community centre offered programs for all age groups daily
The shopping centre attracted visitors from surrounding towns regularly
The party moved toward the centre to appeal to moderate voters
Centre politics sought compromise between progressive and conservative positions

definitions: Orthodox Jewish Hasidic movement emphasizing outreach, education, and mystical teachings of Lubavitch tradition
examples: The Chabad center provided kosher meals for traveling Jewish students
Chabad rabbis established educational programs in communities worldwide extensively

definitions: series of connected metal rings or links used for fastening or pulling
group of stores or restaurants owned by the same company
series of connected events, actions, or things forming a sequence
surveying measurement unit equal to 66 feet or 22 yards
examples: The heavy chain secured the gate against unauthorized entry effectively
She wore a delicate gold chain around her neck daily
The restaurant chain expanded to fifty locations across three states
Chain stores often offer consistent products and pricing nationwide
The chain of events led inevitably to the company's bankruptcy
Breaking one link in the supply chain disrupted entire operations
Surveyors measured property boundaries using chains before modern equipment
The plot measured exactly ten chains along its eastern border

definitions: something that has been caught, especially fish or game
device for fastening or securing a door, window, or container
hidden problem or disadvantage in an apparently ideal situation
total quantity of fish or game caught during a specific period
examples: The fisherman's catch included several large salmon and trout
Today's catch will be served fresh at tonight's dinner
The cabinet catch needed adjustment to keep doors closed properly
A magnetic catch held the jewelry box lid securely shut
The deal seemed perfect, but there had to be a catch
Read the contract carefully to find any hidden catches
The season's catch exceeded last year's total by twenty percent
Commercial fishing boats reported their catch to regulatory authorities

definitions: baseball player positioned behind home plate who catches pitched balls
device or person that catches things, especially in industrial or agricultural contexts
examples: The catcher signaled for a fastball with two fingers extended
Professional catchers wear extensive protective gear during games
The grain catcher prevented valuable wheat from scattering during harvest
Dream catchers originated in Native American Ojibwe culture traditionally

definitions: action or process of capturing or grasping something in motion
quality of being infectious or likely to spread from person to person
examples: Catching the ball required perfect timing and hand-eye coordination
The art of catching butterflies demands patience and gentle technique
Her enthusiasm was catching, spreading throughout the entire team quickly
Laughter proved catching as the whole audience began giggling together

definitions: area from which rainfall flows into a river, lake, or reservoir
geographical area served by an institution like a school or hospital
examples: The river's catchment area covered three hundred square kilometers total
Deforestation in the catchment region increased flooding risk significantly
The hospital's catchment included five surrounding suburban districts entirely
School catchment boundaries determined student enrollment eligibility strictly

definitions: well-known phrase or expression associated with a particular person, group, or product
examples: The comedian's catchphrase became part of popular culture overnight
Political campaigns often develop catchphrases to summarize their message

definitions: process of organizing things into groups based on shared characteristics or criteria
examples: Product categorisation helps customers navigate online shopping sites efficiently
The library's categorisation system followed established international standards precisely

definitions: process of organizing items into categories based on common features or characteristics
examples: Automatic categorization of emails helps manage inbox overflow effectively
The categorization of species follows strict taxonomic principles scientifically

definitions: class or division of people or things regarded as having particular shared characteristics
fundamental concept or class of concepts in philosophy and logic
examples: Products were arranged by category to simplify customer shopping experience
The award had separate categories for fiction and non-fiction works
Aristotle identified ten categories of being in his philosophical system
Kant's categories of understanding structure how we perceive reality fundamentally
